Scheme 1 The scheme for preparation of ZrO2 C800-S. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 SEM images of (a) C800, (b) C800-S, (c) ZrO2 C800, and (d) ZrO2 C800-S; (e-k) The EDS elemental mapping for ZrO2 C800-S. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm curves and (b) pore size distribution curves of the catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Raman spectra of the catalysts. Fig 4 Fig. 5 FT-IR spectra of the catalysts. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) C 1 s, (b) O 1 s, (c) Zr 3d, and (d) S 2p spectra of the catalysts. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Pyridine-FTIR spectra of the catalyst. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Effect of (a) solvent, (b) reaction temperature, (c) reaction time, (d) catalyst dosage on reaction. Reaction condition: 0.05 g xylose, 0.05 g catalyst, 5.0 mL GVL at 190 °C for 90 min. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Effect of (a) solvents, (b) ratios of THF and water, (c) salt solutions, and (d) catalyst dosage on the reaction. Reaction condition: 0.05 g fructose or glucose, 0.05 g catalyst, 4.0 mL THF, 1.0 mL aqueous NaCl. Conversion of fructose to HMF at 160 °C for 60 min. Conversion of glucose to HMF at 180 °C for 2.5 h Fig 9 Fig. 10 Effect of (a) reaction temperature and (b) time on the fructose transformation. Effect of (c) reaction temperature and (d) time on the glucose transformation. Reaction condition: 0.05 g fructose or glucose, 0.05 g catalyst, 4.0 mL THF, 1.0 mL aqueous NaCl. Fig 10 Fig. 11 Cyclic tests of ZrO2 C800-S catalyst. Reaction conditions for the conversion of xylose to FF: 0.05 g xylose, 0.05 g catalyst, 5.0 mL GVL at 190 °C for 90 min. Hanzhong 723200 China cHanzhong City Pengyuan Biotechnology Co., Ltd., Hanzhong 723200, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural obtained from sugars can be transformed into various chemicals. Conversion of sugars to furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural are the typical reactions for the biomass feedstock transformation. In this study, a charcoal-based catalyst with acidic sites of Lewis and Brønsted acids was prepared to achieve an effective conversion of biomass sugars (xylose, glucose, and fructose) to furan compounds. By loading zirconium dioxide on the charcoal-based materials and then sulfonating it, the Lewis and Brønsted acids in the prepared solid acidic catalyst can be regulated to a suitable ratio. Under the optimal reaction condition, the furfural yield from xylose was 94.9 %, and the 5-hydroxymethylfurfural yields from glucose and fructose were 72.2 % and 99.9 %, respectively. Furthermore, a variety of sugars and agricultural wastes can be transformed into the corresponding furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural in satisfactory yields over the catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Solid acids Xylose Glucose Fructose Furfural 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass, as an alternative to fossil fuels resource, is of increasing interest to researchers because it can be converted into high-value chemicals [1,2]. Among them, biomass agricultural wastes such as corn stover, rice straw, and wheat straw etc. have received great attention due to that the rich cellulose and hemicellulose in them can be hydrolyzed to furfural (FF) and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), which are recognized as the biomass platform molecules and can be further converted into a variety of chemicals [3,4]. FF is usually produced by the conversion of pentose sugars (e.g. xylose) catalyzed by Brønsted acid. HMF, on the other hand, is usually produced by the conversion of hexoses (e.g., glucose, fructose, etc.) with the reaction process of that glucose is converted to fructose with a suitable Lewis acid by isomerization, and then HMF is formed by dehydration of fructose with the help of Brønsted acid [4,5]. In the earliest studies, it was common to use liquid mineral acids to catalyze the synthesis of furan compounds from sugars [6]. Soluble metal chloride salts such as Al3+, Ga3+, In3+, and Sn4+, etc. have good acidity and can catalyze the conversion of sugars to HMF [7]. Catalytic systems of inorganic mineral acids and metal chloride salts are widely used to efficiently convert poplar wood chips to FF and HMF in 1,4-dioxane/water solvents [8]. However, these homogeneous catalysts have the disadvantages of difficult product separation, difficult catalyst recovery, and vessel corrosion. Therefore, exploring a non-homogeneous catalytic system for biomass conversion has received extensive attentions. A variety of non-homogeneous solid acid catalyst have been explored for the conversion of sugars to furan compounds, such as zeolites, exchanged ion resins, metal oxides, etc. [9-14]. Among them, carbon-based solid acids with high acid density have attracted the attention of researchers. Dulie et al. catalyzed the conversion of xylose to FF in 62.4 % yield using one-step charring of sulfonated straw with concentrated sulfuric acid [15]. Zhang et al. synthesized SSAC solid acids by sulfonating sucrose with isoamyl nitrite and p-aminobenzenesulfonic acid to give 78.8 % yield of FF from wheatgrass [16]. Doping metal ions with Lewis acids into carbon based solid acid materials can effectively improve their catalytic activity. Li et al. prepared sulfonated microsphere catalysts CCo-S containing cobalt ions for catalytic conversion of corn cob to FF with 70 % yield [17]. Xing et al. prepared a complex of charcoal-based solid acid catalysts containing FePO4 and adjusted the Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites to achieve a 58.6 % yield of HMF from glucose [18]. Thus charcoal-based solid acid catalysts with both acid sites of Lewis and Brønsted acid are expected to be ideal catalyst candidates for the conversion of biomass sugars to furans. In addition to the catalyst, the solvent can significantly influence the catalysis in the reaction process. Currently, single-phase solvent (organic solvents and aqueous solvents), ionic liquid, biphasic solvent, and deep eutectic solvent are widely used [19]. Biphasic solvents of organic solvents and water have been of interest to researchers due to that sugars are soluble in water while furan products are more inclined to be soluble in organic solvents, which leads to rapid extraction and protection of the generated furans into the organic phase, thus increasing the yield [20]. In addition, the addition of inorganic salts (NaCl, KCl, etc.) can effectively increase the partition coefficients of furan compounds in the organic phase and further improve the selectivity for them [21]. Consequently, the two-phase solvent of organic and salts aqueous solvent is suitable for the conversion of sugar to furan. In the present work, a ZrO2 modified sulfonated charcoal-based catalysts with both Lewis and Brønsted acid was prepared and characterized to investigate the catalytic performance for conversion of xylose, glucose, and fructose to the corresponding furans. The reaction condition was optimized. The catalyst stability was investigated and the cause for the slightly declination of the catalytic performance was disclosed. Besides the transformation of the above three sugars, the present catalytic system showed satisfied catalytic conversion of different sugars and agricultural wastes to the corresponding furans. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparations Preparation of Cx. Lignin, potassium oxalate, and calcium carbonate in the mass ratio of 1:1:1 was mixed into a mortar and thoroughly ground. Then, the mixture was transferred into a crucible and allowed to be charred in a tube furnace at a certain temperature under argon atmosphere at 800 °C with raising the temperature of 3 °C/min and keeping it for 1 h The black mixture was washed twice with 2.0 mol/L hydrochloric acid followed by water until the pH of the filtrate was neutral. Finally, the black mixture was dried at 80 °C overnight. The dried sample was abbreviated as Cx, where x represented the calcining temperature. Preparation of ZrO2 Cx. Lignin, potassium oxalate, and calcium carbonate in the mass ratio of 1:1:1 was mixed into a mortar and thoroughly ground. Then a certain amount of zirconium chloride (molar ratio of zirconium chloride to lignin was 1:1) was added, mixed well and ball-milled for 3 h Then, the mixture was transferred into a crucible and charred in a tube furnace under argon atmosphere at 800 °C with an elevated temperature of 3 °C/min and kept for 1 h The black mixture was washed with 2.0 mol/L hydrochloric acid followed by water until the pH of the filtrate was neutral. Finally, the black mixture was dried at 80 °C overnight. The dried samples were abbreviated as ZrO2 C x . The mass ratio of lignin to zirconium chloride of 1:0.5 and 1:1.5 was used as control catalysts, abbreviated as ZrO2 C x (1:0.5) and ZrO2 C x (1:1.5). Sulfonation of the catalysts. In a round-bottom flask, 1 g of ZrO2 C x and 4 g of p-aminobenzenesulfonic acid were added into 150 mL water and stirred for 30 min. 2 g of amyl nitrite was then added and the temperature was raised to 80 °C and stirred under reflux for 12 h The obtained solid was washed repeatedly with ethanol and water until the filtrate reached neutrality. Subsequently, the filter cake was dried at 80 °C overnight. The dried sample was named as ZrO2 C x -S. C x was sulfonated as a control catalyst by the method described above, abbreviated as C x -S (Scheme 1 ). 2.2 Characterizations Hitachi S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) was employed to obtain the morphology of the catalysts. JEM-F200 transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used to characterize the microstructure of the catalysts. VECTOR-22 was applied to conduct the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra with a resolution of 2 cm-1. X-ray diffractometer (XRD) of Rigaku D/max2500 was applied to characterize the crystallinity of the catalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using Thermo Fisher's ESCALAB 250Xi electronic spectrometer, using a monochromatic Al Kα (mono Al Kα) radiation source (1486.6 eV). All binding energies were corrected based on the C 1 s peak (284.6 eV). Micromeritics ASAP 2460 was used to measure the textural properties by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption. Tensor 27 Fourier infrared spectrometer was employed to measure the Pyridine-FTIR spectra (Py-FTIR) with a resolution of 4 cm-1. PerkinElmer Lamda 950 spectrometer was used to test the ultraviolet absorption spectra. 2.3 Catalytic performance Typically, a 0.05 g sugar, 0.05 g catalyst, and 5.0 mL solvent were added to the reaction vessel, and then heated to the desired temperature. After reaction, it was quenched using an ice water bath. The obtained reaction solution was analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with a C18 column (Supersil ODS2) at 261 nm detection. The mobile phase was methanol and water (V/V = 2/8) with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The yield of the product was determined by the external standard method as follows: (1) HMF yield ( from biomass ) = Moles of produced HMF Moles of glucose unit in biomass × 100 % (2) Furfural yield ( from biomass ) = Moles of produced furfural Moles of xylose unit in biomass × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the catalysts To understand morphologies of the catalysts, SEM characterization was conducted. The surface of charcoal-based C800 calcined at 800 °C is bulk (Fig. 1 a). After the introduction of zirconium oxide, the surface structure of ZrO2 C800 changes significantly, with smaller particles and stacking (Fig. 1c). After sulfonation, C800-S and ZrO2 C800-S show obvious pores (Fig. 1b and d), indicating that sulfonation influences the carbon morphology structure. The elemental distributions were further analyzed using EDS (Fig. 1e-1i). The elemental profiles show a highly uniform distribution of C, O, Zr, and S, implying the zirconia and sulfonic acid group are successfully introduced to the catalysts. In addition, a small amount of Ca2+ and K + residues can be found. To analyze the pore structure, nitrogen adsorption-desorption tests were carried out (Fig. 2 ). The isotherms of C800 and C800-S are of type I, indicating a microporous structure. ZrO2 C800 and ZrO2 C800-S have type II isotherms, indicating a macroporous structure [22,23]. The specific surface area reduces from 502 m2/g for C800 to 349 m2/g for ZrO2 C800. After sulfonation, the surface areas of C800-S and ZrO2 C800-S are greatly reduced to 110 and 130 m2/g (Table S1), indicating that the sulfonation process affects their structures [24,25]. The crystalline structures were analyzed by XRD (Fig. 3 ). C800 and C800-S show a broad peak at 23°, corresponding to a characteristic peak of amorphous structures [26]. After the introduction of zirconium oxide, several new peaks at 30.1, 34.9, 50.3, 59.6, 62.7, and 73.8° appear in ZrO2 C800 and ZrO2 C800-S. They are typical characteristic peaks of monoclinic ZrO2 phase (JCPDS: 49–1642) corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), and (400) crystal planes, suggesting that zirconium oxide is successfully introduced and the sulfonation has little influence on the zirconium oxide structure in ZrO2 C800 [27]. To further investigate the structure of the catalyst, Raman spectra of the charcoal samples were measured (Fig. 4 ). The peak at 1340 cm-1 corresponds to the D band, which is due to the disordered structure of the charcoal material. The peak at 1590 cm-1 corresponds to the G band, which indicates the ordered structure of graphitic carbon. The gradual decrease in the I D /I G values of C800-S, ZrO2 C800 and ZrO2 C800-S compared with C800 indicates the decrease in the degree of amorphousness of the catalyst due to the introduction of zirconia and grafting of sulfonic acid groups [16]. To analyze the functional groups of the prepared catalysts, they were characterized by the FT-IR. As shown in Fig. 5 , all catalysts show typical absorption peaks at 1719 and 1570 cm-1, corresponding to the stretching vibration of C = O and aromatic C = C in the charcoal-based structure, respectively [28-30]. The absorption peaks at 1409 and 2847–2967 cm-1 correspond to the CH stretching vibrations in -CH2- due to incomplete charring of the sample [31,32]. In addition, the broad peaks at approximately 1047 cm-1 in C800 are recognized as the complex results of CO stretching, benzene ring respiration, aromatic CH bending vibrations, and CO bending vibrations [33,34]. After sulfonation of ZrO2 C800, ZrO2 C800-S shows characteristic peaks at 1180, 1125, 1037, and 1005 cm-1, which are attributed to the -PhSO3H groups [16], proving the successful introduction of the sulfonic acid group. XPS was used to further characterize the surface chemical environment of the carbon-based series of catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the peaks of C1 s spectra can be decomposed into four peaks at 284.6, 285.6, 286.9, and 289.5 eV, corresponding to aliphatic and/or aromatic groups (C–Hx and C–C/C = C), alcohol and/or ether groups (–C–O), carbonyl groups (C = O), and carboxyl groups COOH [35]. This indicates that the obtained carbon materials possess abundant defects and oxygen-contained functional groups, which would benefit the grafting of sulfonic acid groups. In the O1 s spectra (Fig. 6b), the peak of C800 sample can be decomposed into two peaks at 532.5 and 533.9 eV, corresponding to CO and C = O [36], repsectively. The introduction of zirconium oxide shifts the binding energy to a higher direction (532.6 and 534.1 eV) in ZrO2 C800 [37]. After sulfonation of ZrO2 C800, an S-O peak appears at 531.1 eV [38]. The binding energies of Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 migrate from 183.6 and 185.9 eV in ZrO2 C800 to 183.3 and 185.6 eV in ZrO2 C800-S (Fig. 6c), respectively. It suggests the existence of the interaction between doped ZrO2 and -SO3H. For the S2p spectra, the peak can be divided into two peaks at 168.0 and 169.2 eV corresponding to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2, respectively, which indicates the successful grafting of the sulfonic acid groups [29]. The acidic types and contents were determined by pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 7 , Lewis acidic site (L) is at 1618 and 1448 cm-1 while Brønsted acidic site (B) is at 1637 and 1541 cm-1. Lewis and Brønsted acid sites (L + B) contribute to the absorption at 1491 cm-1 [39,40]. A low content of Brønsted acid is detected in the C800 sample, which is attributed to the surface COOH and -OH groups [41]. The Lewis acid sites on C800 and C800-S are due to the partial Ca2+ and K + remaining during the preparation of the catalyst [42]. With graft of the sulfonic acid group on C800, the Lewis acid and Brønsted acid contents of C800-S are substantially increased (Table 1 ). Compared with C800, the total acid density of ZrO2 C800 is slightly decreased due to the decrease in the proportion of carbon by the zirconium oxide doping. After grafting the sulfonic acid group on ZrO2 C800, ZrO2 C800-S (1:1) has the highest B acid content. These indicate that introduction of ZrO2 in the char-based carbon can regulate the content and molar ratio of Lewis and Brønsted acids. In addition, the mass ratio of lignin to zirconium chloride greatly affects the contents of Brønsted acid and Lewis acid (Table 1, entries 4–6), especially the content of Brønsted acid. When mass ratio of carbon source to zirconium chloride is 1:1, the contents of Brønsted acid and Lewis acid reach the highest. The appropriate acid content and the suitable ratio of Lewis and Brønsted acids can significantly affect sugars hydrolysis reaction [43]. 3.2 Catalytic performances The catalytic performances for the transformation of biomass sugars to furans, including xylose to FF, glucose and fructose to HMF, were evaluated using prepared catalysts (Table 2 ). The yields are low without catalysts, indicating that the catalysts have a key role in the sugar hydrolysis reaction (Table 2, entry 1). Compared with the catalytic performances over C800, the yield of FF from xylose is greatly improved from 26.6 % to 79.3 % over C800-S and the yield of HMF from glucose increases from 37.6 % to 52.9 % (Table 2, entry 1). But the yield of HMF from fructose varies little. Compared with C800, the Brønsted acid and Lewis acid centers of C800-S are substantially higher, so it leads to a substantial increase in yields (Entries 2 and 3). This suggests that Brønsted acid and Lewis acid play major roles in the hydrolysis of sugars [44]. Low catalytic activity over ZrO2 C800 (Table 2, entry 4) is due to insufficient Brønsted and Lewis acidity. Compared with the other catalysts mentioned above, ZrO2 C800-S has the best catalytic performances, resulting in 94.9 % yield of FF from xylose and 72.2 % and 99.9 % yield of HMF from glucose and fructose, respectively (Table 2, entry 6). Although C800-S (B acid 21.4 μmol/g, L acid 38.9 μmol/g) and ZrO2 C800-S (B acid 25.6 μmol/g, L acid 31.8 μmol/g) have similar Brønsted and Lewis acidity level, they exhibit very different catalytic performances, indicating that B/L value affects the catalytic performances and proper B/L value can synergistically achieve the good yield [45]. In addition, similar B/L value of ZrO2 C800 (B/L value 0.89) and ZrO2 C800-S (B/L value 0.81) shows very different catalytic performances (Table 2, entries 4 and 6), implying that besides the B/L value the acidic contents of Brønsted and Lewis acid also have significant effect on the catalytic performances. In addition, the mass ratio of carbon and zirconium chloride for preparation of ZrO2 C800-S influences the catalytic performances. It is found that too little or too much zirconium oxide is responsible for the decrease in yield (Table 2, entries 5–7), which is due to that the contents and ratio of Brønsted and Lewis acid of the catalyst are affected by the introduction of ZrO2 and, consequently, influence the catalytic performances. It can be found the contents of Brønsted in ZrO2 C800-S (1:0.5) and ZrO2 C800-S (1:1.5) are much lower than that of ZrO2 C800-S (1:1). But the catalytic performances of them are not varied as great as their contents of Brønsted acid. This indicates that Lewis acid are also the activate sites for transformation of xylose, glucose, and fructose to FF and HMF. Moreover, the calcination temperature for preparation of the catalyst was optimized (Table 2, entries 6, 8, and 9). It can be found the calcination temperature of 800 °C is the highest for the yields. This is because that the calcination temperature can affect the content of the oxygen-contained functional groups (Fig. S1), consequently affecting the sulfonation process. 3.2.1 Preparation of furfural from xylose For conversion of xylose to FF, suitable solvent can enhance the solubility of xylose and inhibit side reactions [45]. Therefore, catalytic performances in different solvents were investigated (Fig. 8 a). In water solvent, the yield of FF is only 23.4 %, which is due to the instability of FF in water and the easy formation of by-products with the reaction intermediates leading to a decrease in the yield [46]. The lowest yield of FF in dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (11.8 %) is due to the hydrolysis of the ester under acidity, which is not conducive to FF production [7]. Xylose is poorly soluble in 1,4-dioxane, dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), and tetrahydrofuran (THF), resulting in large number of xylose molecules that are poorly dispersed and aggregated together and leading to the occurrence of polymerization side reactions and poor yields [29]. Compared with the above mentioned solvents, the highest yield of FF (94.9 %) is achieved in γ-valerolactone (GVL), which is attributed to the stabilizing effect of GVL on the reacting acidic protons so that the activation energy required for the xylose production of FF catalyzed by acidic protons is reduced [47]. The effects of temperature and reaction time on FF yield are examined in Fig. 8b and 8c, respectively. With an increase in reaction temperature, the FF yield grows from 22.0 % at 160 °C to 94.9 % at 190 °C, but the yield decreases to 64.9 % at 200 °C as the temperature continues to increase. With an increase in reaction time, the FF yield increases from 28.9 % at 45 min to 94.9 % at 90 min, but the yield decreases to 67.3 % at 105 min. These indicate that high temperature and long reaction time are favorable for the reaction, but too high temperature and too long reaction time contribute to the occurrence of side reactions, resulting in low yield [48]. Fig. 8d examines the effect of catalyst loading on FF yield. Low loading of catalyst (25 mg) results in insufficient catalytic acidic sites, leading to poor yield (64.2 %), but too high amount of catalyst (75 mg, 100 mg) leads to an overabundance of acidic sites causing side reactions to occur [49]. The best FF yield is achieved at a catalyst loading of 50 mg. 3.2.2 Preparation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural from glucose and fructose The effect of solvents on production of HMF from glucose and fructose was investigated in Fig. 9 a. Compared with water, the yield of HMF is better for fructose transformation in organic solvent, due to the easy hydrolysis of HMF in water [50]. DMSO has the highest yield, followed by THF and 1,4-dioxane, which is attributed to the strong proton attractivity of DMSO, which contributes that it is more favorable to extract proton from fructose to produce HMF [51]. Regarding glucose conversion, THF, as a medium to high alkalinity solvent, has better catalytic properties than other solvents. HMF in single-phase solvent tends to condense with itself or the substrate. In biphasic solvents, the organic phase rapidly extracts and protects the generated furans, effectively inhibiting side reactions [20,51,52]. In these biphasic solvents, THF possesses the highest partition coefficient, making it the best candidate in extracting HMF from the water phase [7,52]. The volume ratio of THF to water has a great influence on the HMF yields obtained from fructose and glucose (Fig. 9b,). The highest HMF yield can be obtained when the volume ratio is 8:2. Chloride salts can increase the partition coefficient of HMF during its extraction in the two-phase solvent, thus facilitating the reaction [53,54]. Furthermore, the chloride anion can enhance the isomerization of glucose to fructose and the fructose dehydration to HMF [55,56]. Consequently, chloride salts are used to investigate their influence on the two-phase solvent catalytic systems. Compared with the two-phase solvents without chloride salts, the change of HMF yields is varied with different salts. As shown in Fig. 9c, the positive effect of the addition of chloride salts in the conversion of fructose to HMF is in the order of NaCl>NH4Cl>CaCl2>no salt>ZnCl2>FeCl3. For the conversion of glucose to HMF, the yields of HMF reduces in the order of NaCl>CaCl2>no salt>NH4Cl>ZnCl2>FeCl3. The strong negative influence of FeCl3 is due to its strong Lewis acid that accelerates the side reactions of HMF converted from glucose. Since both conversion of glucose and fructose has best performances in aqueous NaCl solution, the two-phase THF-NaCl aqueous solution is employed for the following studies. The effect of catalyst dosage on the catalytic performance is examined in Fig. 9d. In the absence of catalyst, the HMF yield from glucose (35.6 %) is higher than that from fructose (12.4 %), which suggests that the effect of salt on the conversion of glucose is more significant than that of fructose without catalyst. The HMF yields of both glucose and fructose are improved and then declined with the amount of catalysts increase. The growth of the catalyst dosage can provide more active acid sites. However, too much catalyst dosage can lead to more HMF consumption by side reactions [57]. And this is supported by the fact that the reaction solution deepened in color with the dosage of catalyst increased (Fig. S2). The reaction temperature and time were subsequently studied. Both yield of HMF enhances with the increase of temperature and then decreases. Among them, the yield from fructose increases from 50.1 % at 140 °C to 99.9 % at 160 °C and then decreases gradually (Fig. 10 a), while the yield from glucose shows the highest yield at 180 °C (Fig. 10c). As shown in the Fig. 10b and 10d, the yields of HMF show an alike trend with the extension of the reaction time, with the highest yield at 60 min for fructose transformation and 2.5 h for glucose transformation. The degradation and polymerization of HMF would be intensified when the reaction temperature is too high or reaction time is too long [58-61]. Under the optimized reaction condition, the HMF yields from fructose and glucose are 99.9 % and 72.2 %, respectively, and the FF yield from xylose is 94.9 %. 3.3 Catalyst stability To examine the stability of the catalyst, the catalyst was reused 5 times under optimal conditions. As shown in Fig. 11 a, the yields are slightly decreased with the reused cycles increase. The yield of xylose to FF after 5 consecutive use is 50.9 %. The yields of glucose and fructose to HMF are 55.7 % and 71.1 %, respectively. It is reported that the decline of the catalytic activity is inevitable for the carbon-based solid acid catalyst [24,29,62,63]. To explore the declination reason of the prepared catalyst, the used catalyst was characterized. There is no obvious change in the catalyst morphology before and after the reaction (Fig. S3). The XRD peaks of the catalysts are basically the same, and the peaks of zirconia are unchanged (Fig. S4). An increase in the intensity of the peaks approximately at 1210 and 1480 cm-1 in the catalyst after use is found in the IR spectrum (Fig. S5), which is caused by the CO and C = C telescopic vibration of the furan ring structure of humin stacked on the surface of the catalyst. In addition, the appearance of the absorption peaks of humin in the UV spectra (Fig. S6) of used catalyst indicates that the build-up of by-products during the reaction process leads to the clogging of the catalyst pores, which is partly responsible for the decrease in catalyst activity. In addition, the total acidity of the fresh and used catalyst is determined by acid-base titration. The total acidity of the fresh catalyst is 1.05 mmol/g. The total acidity of the five-time used catalyst (0.73 mmol/g) is significantly lower than that of the fresh catalyst. The loss of some acid sites is the main reason for the decrease in catalyst activity. With the decline reasons in hand, the catalyst is regenerated to recover the catalytic performance. The reacted catalyst is washed with water and methanol, impregnated with 1 mol/L H2SO4 for 8 h and then washed by water until the pH of the filtrate was neutral. After regeneration, the total acidity of the catalyst (1.03 mmol/g) is brought back to the same level as the fresh catalyst, and its yield is greatly restored. The catalytic transformation of xylose is further examined (Fig. 11b). After every five cycles, the catalyst was regenerated. It can be found that the declination trends are similar in every five cycles. However, the highest yield of furfural from xylose achieved by the regenerated catalyst after each set of five cycles decreases. 3.4 Expansion of the substrates Due to a good performance of ZrO2 C800-S catalyst, the versatility of the present catalytic system was examined by using a variety of carbohydrate sugars and biomass wastes as substrates under optimal reaction conditions. The present catalytic system gives excellent yields for the preparation of HMF from fructose (Table 3 , entry 1). It also gives satisfactory HMF or FF yields for other hexoses or pentoses (Table 3, entries 2–7). Biomass agricultural wastes such as corn cob, corn stalk, rice straw, wheat straw, and rice husk are rich in cellulose and hemicellulose, which can be hydrolyzed by acid catalysis to produce HMF and FF. As shown in entries 8–12, in this catalytic system, there are better yields of FF compared with HMF, which is due to the lax structure of hemicellulose that is more susceptible to the formation of xylose for further production of FF [2]. The yields of FF and HMF from biomass agricultural waste are commonly lower than that of sugars. This is because that the sugars are soluble in the mixture solvent under the reaction conditions but the biomass agricultural waste is insoluble, leading the contact of the catalyst and the solid agricultural waste (mass and heat transfer) is less than that of sugars. In addition, the yields are varied for different biomass agricultural waste. This is attributed that the content of hemicellulose and cellulose are different for different plant, even same plant in different planting areas is also varied [30]. 4 Conclusion The ZrO2 C800-S bifunctional solid acid catalysts with both Brønsted and Lewis bis-acid sites were prepared by solid-phase calcination followed by sulfonation using lignin as the carbon source. The characteristic shows that the zirconium dioxide doping and sulfonation of the char-based materials decreased the surface area. The doped zirconium dioxide can affect the contents and ratio of Brønsted to Lewis acid. The yield of FF from xylose can reach 94.9 % in GVL solvent while the yield of HMF from fructose and glucose can reach 72.2 and 99.9 % in the biphasic THF-NaCl aqueous solution, respectively. The stability of the catalyst reveals that the yield of FF and HMF is slightly declined due to the loss of the acidity, cover of humin on the catalyst. The catalytic performance can be restored after regeneration but the highest efficiency achieved by the catalyst after each set of five cycles decreases. In addition, the catalyst can be used for the conversion of a variety of sugars and agricultural wastes to t 5-hydroxymethylfurfural or furfural. coredata.dc:description: Furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural obtained from sugars can be transformed into various chemicals. Conversion of sugars to furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural are the typical reactions for the biomass feedstock transformation. In this study, a charcoal-based catalyst with acidic sites of Lewis and Brønsted acids was prepared to achieve an effective conversion of biomass sugars (xylose, glucose, and fructose) to furan compounds. By loading zirconium dioxide on the charcoal-based materials and then sulfonating it, the Lewis and Brønsted acids in the prepared solid acidic catalyst can be regulated to a suitable ratio. Under the optimal reaction condition, the furfural yield from xylose was 94.9 %, and the 5-hydroxymethylfurfural yields from glucose and fructose were 72.2 % and 99.9 %, respectively. Furthermore, a variety of sugars and agricultural wastes can be transformed into the corresponding furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural in satisfactory yields over the catalyst.
